content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would analyze this game strategically to maximize my earnings over the 75 rounds.

If we consider only the immediate payoffs, it might seem that picking B is beneficial because it offers a guaranteed return of 20$ in case the opponent picks R. However, if we examine the long-term strategy, it becomes apparent that the dominant strategy for maximizing earnings is to pick R.

Here's why: In this game, the opponent gets a higher payoff when I pick B (40$) than when I pick R (20$ or 0$). This means they have an incentive to encourage me to pick B more often, so they can maximize their earnings. On the other hand, if I pick R consistently, my earnings will be 45$ per round whenever they pick R as well, which gives me a higher average payoff over time.

By picking R in this game, I can make my opponent choose B more often, increasing my overall earnings. If I pick B, my opponent would likely pick R more frequently, leading to fewer high-payoff rounds for me. So, my choice would be {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, if I stick with my strategy of picking R consistently, I should continue to do so in the next round as well. By doing so, I can encourage my opponent to pick B again in the hope of receiving a higher payoff for themselves. If they pick B and I pick R, then I will receive 45$ in the future round when they switch back to picking R.

However, if my opponent starts noticing that my consistent R choices are leading them to pick B more frequently, they might adapt their strategy and begin picking R more often as well. In such a case, we could end up in a situation where neither of us maximizes our earnings over the 75 rounds.

Regardless, my initial analysis still suggests that picking R is the dominant strategy for me to maximize my overall earnings in this game, given the payoff structure and the number of rounds. So, I will continue to pick R in the next round as well.

If this pattern continues, I will alternate between picking R and B, while my opponent will consistently pick R. In this scenario, my average earnings would be approximately 22.5$ per round, which is higher than the guaranteed 20$ if I were to consistently pick B. However, it's important to note that my opponent would also have a higher-than-average payoff (37.5$) in this pattern due to my R choices encouraging them to pick B more frequently.

While picking R still seems like the dominant strategy for maximizing my overall earnings over the 75 rounds, following the same strategy rigidly could lead us both to have lower-than-optimal payoffs due to our patterns becoming predictable. Adapting our strategies in response to each other's choices may be necessary to achieve the highest possible payoff in this game. However, without knowing my opponent's potential adaptation and how they reason, it is difficult to make a definitive choice for future rounds.
